WRITING.TITLE: What chore do you just love doing?
WRITING.TEXT: I love matching socks, taking out the trash, and unloading the dishwasher isn't too bad either.
I would rather mow 5 lawns and trim 10 bushes than do the dishes. I have this strange aversion getting my hands wet over and over... Kitchen gloves might help, but I usually still get wet.
Never broken a limb. Never been a patient at a hospital besides the day I was born.
Sadly, parents of down syndrome kids often never move out, and the parenting effort is much more intense. Those parents are some of the bravest people I know.
We are both an air conditioner and a heater.
The turtle is hunting for a nap?
Wow I didn't know that kind of rule could even be enforced.
It all depends on how you define your coordinate system! (snarky physics teacher response)
TIL What a corn light is

This just gave an idea for a Reddit Bot - the Dupe Comment Bot. Reddit needs a way for users to know when they have posted the same comment twice in a short window of time. I've never written a bot, but how hard can it be?
#32 is totally fake, though
These are screaming for captions! Love it.

According to [this website](https://portal.ehawaii.gov/residents/newcomers-guide/interisland-flights-and-ferries/) there are no ferries to the Big Island from anywhere.
Lol bug island... My first impression of the big island was a bunch of cockroaches in Kailua-Kona running around on the stone walls. Isn't stopping me from moving there in the Winter!

I'm not a recent grad, and I wasn't a CS major (I did business / management information systems), but I would say that writing up spec/design documents is sorely missing from most IT-related education. As a consultant, I'm writing designs (whether it's in an email or document) about 25% of the time, and I would say that makes the difference between a good developer and a great one.
The larger the company, the greater potential for politics. I have worked at a small company (25 people) for 9 years and politics rarely come up.
Why. You could solve so many international conflicts, solve crimes, learn the meaning of life, etc.

Yes, the Bullet Ant of South America, and it's the worst one. Read more [here](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paraponera_clavata) under "initiation rites", and the kids must do it 20 times over a few months to become a warrior!
Grasshopper
This must be a typo - 15 mph is 24 kph, not 40 kph. Since 25 mph is actually pretty fast, and converts to 40 kph, I believe it should be 25 mph in the article.
I do notice other men's haircuts, and I like to call them "Hey haircut" the first time I see them after a haircut. I usually get a little grin...

When we talk on the phone to another man, we are usually looking to get to the point, so we don't waste too much with small talk. We may joke in a way that seems harsh, and we end it as soon as the goal is reached. To woman's ear, it can sound like we are being short or insensitive with each other, but we know it's just how men communicate.
Unless you want that person to be financially dependent on you... attractive again!
Maybe it means they don't care about what the world thinks of them? They might also be financially savvy, since driving super nice cars gets real expensive.
This is why I'm moving to Hawaii in a few months!
"Hack your insert area of life". Why not just call it improvement, or growth, or something that doesn't sound illegal?

I recently was approved to be a remote employee so I'm moving to Hawaii this winter while keeping my "Silicon Valley" salary. Hours are 6 AM - 2 PM M-F, so I can hit the beach every day! Also: Dogs are allowed in the office, the boss took us all on a cruise to Cabo San Lucas with both penthouses rented out with a butler, free iPhone which can be dual personal/business purpose, and a free iPad.
Same here. Then it was BRAIN: "Insert white substance until this gets funny".

This is especially true in parenting: "Honey, do you want to clean up your toys?" "...no"
It's not fair to expect her to want to do it, so I only ask a question when I am willing to accept any answer, or make it a command instead of a question.
Who came out on top? Snake or fish?
Also - put your bathroom fan on a vacancy sensor switch so you can leave it on and never have to think about turning it off. I did the same for my garage light, now I'm never looking back!

If you just want beaches and don't mind some driving you could try an AirBNB in Makaha or Wainae. We got one for $100/night with an ocean view and full kitchen. It's the complete opposite of Waikiki. Quiet, kinda rural, and lots of locals.

1. Locking your knees while standing at the altar is a nervous habit that can end up in "groom down". Keep 'em loose. 2. You are probably not very comfortable in front of a camera, so try and forget there is a photographer around. Assume the photographer does NOT want "look here and smile" unless they ask you do do that. Focus on each other while being posed and you can't go wrong. 3. You need to intentionally LEAVE the reception at a certain point and decide beforehand a cleanup crew that can deliver any extra stuff back to you. We ended up cleaning up after our own reception afterwards, not tons of fun. 4. You will be in front of people the whole day unless you intervene. Plan to have at least 5 minutes with your new spouse alone at some point after the ceremony, but don't wait until the end of the night. The day is about you, not the guests. Do allow your photographer to capture this (from a distance). 5. You might forget certain family members even exist while lining up for the formal family photos. Do yourself a favor and make a list of the family groupings you want for formal photos and give that to the photographer. Then the deciding is done ahead of time and you can just relax and smile. Photographer don't mind this, as long as you limit the list to just people, and not a scavenger hunt with "photos of the rings" and "dress and shoes" listed. Souce: Am married and a wedding photographer
I'm sure you have tried it, but in the off chance you haven't, try this: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2yDCox-qKbk
We just want something with 3-4 bedrooms, pretty close to the beach, a community with other young families, a good church nearby, fast internet, and pet friendly.

I have worked at this place for 9 years, so I've become critical to their operation. Being a consulting firm, some employees live out of state, but none have been developers and none live in Hawaii. I just sat down with the owner yesterday, explained what I wanted to do, and I had already thought through all the possible objections and had a preliminary plan to ensure I was still productive and contributing. He was not real excited about it, but he did approve it and now we are making plans to move in a few months.
Hey I got my job to approve me working remotely from Hawaii! If I'm going to wear golden handcuffs, at least I can wear them on the beach...

Yep, that's our dream come true. Working in person here in California, we need special permission to leave before 5 PM, so I end up limiting the number of requests. I've still got family in California near by job, so I may try the whole "bring a kid" tactic once in a while to give my wife a break. What line of work are you in?

I was in Oahu in June, it was our first trip there and basically confirmed for us that Oahu was a good option. It's hard to believe there are places in the US in 2016 without high-speed internet access, but I imagine some of those places don't even have indoor plumbing either...
Sweet! I hadn't realized that. For us the "40 hours" a week is minimum, and we are compensated handsomely for every extra hour we put in, so I end up doing more most weeks.

I imagine we'll be back on the mainland by the time the kids are in high school. Thanks for reminding me about high-speed internet, it's a definite must. I'd also like to keep my drive to the airport under 45 minutes so West Hawaii solves that as well.
I am pretty extroverted so I can imagine getting a little bored, but we plan to be part of a church, find other young families nearby, and we have a few acquaintances already on Oahu.

Wife is a stay at home mom, but she may want to pursue education, so I believe Oahu is much better for that. We are including elementary school ratings in our search for a rental. Maui is another possibility, but we feel Oahu/Big Island have so much more to offer in terms of things to do/see. Buying is a possibility, but would need to feel good about staying at that house for 4-5 years for it to make sense, at least that's the conventional wisdom. We own a home in California which we may sell or rent out, not decided on that yet...

I'm aware of the pet regulations, I'm getting my pup's blood drawn this week to start the 120 day waiting period. We will probably not bring her on our "moving" trip, but rather in a subsequent trip back 2 months later (assuming we found pet-friendly housing). My salary will be at least $150k, my wife is a stay-at-home mom. I'm not sure what you mean by "living plans", we are currently planning to get an AirBNB / VRBO place for 2 weeks when we arrive as a base for apartment hunting, then hoping to rent a place for at least 6 months. If we really love it, we may purchase a property.
